items.title: The Triple Threat - nobody likes long tutorials
items.summary: Inspired by mobile game Democracy (which, in turn was inspired by Tripple Town),…
items.content_html:
Inspired by mobile game Democracy (which, in turn was inspired by Tripple Town), I wanted to make a zombie-apocalypse themed game with same mechanics. Mostly because I felt like programming unique unit behaviours would be fun. I shared this idea with a friend and he agreed to take care of graphics and testing.

The first rule of this game is: place 3 (or more) similar units in adjacent tiles and they will be combined into a new one.

So, 3 food units = backpack. And what if we do this process 3 times to combine 3 backpacks?

How about doing these two combinations in one turn?

Every unit had an information card describing it's abilities:

 

For example, as you play the game - crawling zombies would move around the field every 4 turns (notice the filling outline):

And so they could combine themselves:

You could build a big Tank unit that would kill zombies around it:

In total there are 16 unique units, each with their special behaviors: 5 yellow (survivors), 4 blue (defenders), 5 red (zombies). Most of them were created by combining. The gameplay looked something like this:

You could use the helicopter to move a unit from one tile to another, you had a storage slot if you wanted to save some unit for later use, you had dynamite to blow up zombies and get money for that.

The game also featured 10 missions, completing which awarded you extra money, which you could spend in shop:

Each unit affected the chaos\order ballance (red\blue vertical bar), which made you profit more\less from all sources. The goal of the game was to get 100% vaccine development (for a zombe virus). You could do so by building a Curemobiles (level 6 yellow unit), which generated a small % every few turs and by boosting development by 5% for $5000 in shop. 

You lose if you don't have any legit moves. Gameover check required me to check 4 different conditions (is the field filled? can the player use dynamite\helicopter? can he buy one in shop? is his storage slot empty?).

Programming and testing this from ground-up was fun. A lot of testing, a lot of funny bugs and a feeling of acomplishment when everything worked.

In fact, I opened the game to make a few screenshots for this text and spent an hour playing because it's quite addictive.

Now we get to the sad part: there wasn't a lot of people who figured out how to play this game, becasue we were too lazy to develop a proper tutorial.
There were too many things to explain and our tutorial ended up being too long and overloaded with text.

Nobody wants to read a 4-page rulebook before playing a flash game.

You could try though. Play The Triple Thread online here.

items.title: How I made this site - no programming, no hosting bills
items.summary: Today I'm going to tell you how I quickly made this website…
items.content_html:
Today I'm going to tell you how I quickly made this website using Publii and hosted it for free on GitHub Pages.

My goal was to quickly develop and host a simple, yet good-looking portfolio\blog site for free. After some research I found Publii - a no-database CMS, that allows to easily upload to GitHub Pages for a free hosting. And it features a nice set of free themes!

Publii is a free desktop app that allows you to edit and manage your site's content using intuitive user interface. No html\css knowledge required.

(Although, I do know how build sites from scratch, I think using a ready solution is smarter than hand-crafting your site from scratch.)

That's it. I could go more in-depth about setting it up, but there are already plenty of guides on it.

items.title: Goodbye Flash - 6 fun game drafts
items.summary: So, flash started dying and most developers migrated to either HTML5 or Unity\Unreal gamedev.
items.content_html:
So, flash started dying and most developers migrated to either HTML5 or Unity\Unreal gamedev. As a farewell to all the fun times I had with flash - I wanna show you a collection of drafts I did in flash, that didn't become a full game.

  1. No More Rockets
    Did you play Missile Command or Worms?



    Well, I wanted to mix the destructible terrain from Worms and intercepting missles mechanic from MC into a new game. Together with an artist we created this prototype:

    It was going to be a game about your immune system defending against evil bacteria. You control the blue little guy with WASD + LMB to shoot your gun, also you have 4 turrets, that fire slow AoE missles when you press space. I coded the destructible ground and it was a fun challenge, but it didn't go any futher, because both of us had lacked free time and vision on how to wrap this into a full game.
    You can play No More Rockets here.
  2. Chebureki
    A joke game about Oleh Blokhin. Somebody threw a belyash at him once, so my friend offered to make a short joke game about it.
    I used it as an opportunity to learn Box2D - a physics engine for Flash.

    This allowed me to make a complex hitbox for chebureki (half-circle) and outline of our character, which resulted in opportunity to of hilarious stacking:

    You can play Chebureki here.
  3. WarTD
    A dropped attempt to develop a World War themed tower defence game.
    The artist provided gread-looking renders of 3d map, turrets, enemies and explosion aimations, it could be a great game, but we ran out of motivation fast. I enjoyed the challenge of using OOP to program enemy logic, so that we could place waypoints in a visual editor and enemies would turn left\right when they step on it.


    You can play WarTD here.
  4. Crane Master
    Another experiment with Box2d, kind of inspired by those Crane Machines where you could win toys.
    Notice how the guy in the crane is moving his hands when you move the crane, the sawmill animation in the background and the rope physics.
    Once again - fun mechanic to develop and mess around with, but didn't find a way to make a full game out of it.

    You can play Crane Master here. Controls are WASD+Space.
  5. ILoveMyBox
    Yet another effort to create a physics-based game. This was planned to be a platformer about a cat who loves boxes. (Box design inspired by Companion Cube from Portal ♡)

    You can play ILoveMyBox here. Left click to spawn\drag boxes. WASD to move. Warning: jumping doesn't work.
  6. Conveyour Survival
    Yet another try to game a game based on physics. The idea was that you're on a conveyour and need to survive as long as possible. I didn't work long before dropping this one, as you can see.

    You can play Conveyour Survival here.

While we're on the topic of 2d physics-based games: I'd like to recommend "Stick Fight: The Game". It has a lot of levels, great physics, and it's a fun to spend some time if you have 2+ gamepads and a 1+ gamer (girl)friends.

Thanks for reading, if you got this far!

items.title: MonsterCraft 2 - making sequels is hard
items.summary: After good reception of MonsterCraft it was obvious that we should release…
items.content_html:
After good reception of MonsterCraft it was obvious that we should release a sequel. Turns out, making a good sequel is not as easy as it seems - we had to add new stuff without overcomplicating things.

Here is a list of things we decided to do in the sequel:

  • Added in a third race - demons. Demons can't be crafted, but player can capture and use them later in the game.
  • Added an ability to buy armor for your units. So now each unit has 3 tiers: no armor, light armor, heavy armor.
  • Added spells - a way for a player to take part in fights.
  • Made a game longer by adding more worlds\levels.
  • Added a boss in the end of each world. Final boss also tricky and required smart use of spells to win.
  • Added achievements.

You can play MonsterCraft 2 here or watch a let's play:

items.title: Awesome plumber - a tribute to Pipe Mania games
items.summary: My first years of school, affordable mobile phones were a new thing in…
items.content_html:
My first years of school, affordable mobile phones were a new thing in our country. Kids didn't own phones yet and my parents just got their first mobile phone. It was a Samsung C200. (I've no idea how I still remember the model number)

A tiny phone with colorful display and polyphony capable speaker. That was considered a quite advanced device back then.

Being an innate gamer, I used it to play games. My favourite was called "Fun2Link", which was basically a "Pipe Mania" remake:

 

So in I wanted to do a tribute to this game. With the help of my friend, who drew the art, we created a flash game, called "Awesome Plumber".

The goal of the game is to build a path from the oasis, to the yellow "water" container, without letting it overflow. You get stars for water passing through golden pipes.

Also, I added a little easter egg in the title screen: when you hover your cursor over the red "start game" valve - it will spin. The longer you hover the cursor - the faster, no speed limits 😊

You can play Awesome Plumber here.

items.title: Crimson Squad - Trying to make a bigger game
items.summary: This one took a while to finish. Still working with the same…
items.content_html:
This one took a while to finish. Still working with the same team I made Cortex Fortress and MonsterCraft with, we decided to make something more complex: a top-down shooter with a lot of levels, enemy types, weapons, perks, bosses etc.

Our 3d artist rendered 3d models and effects into images so we could simulate 3d in flash. It looked great, but had me struggle a lot with performance: it was the first time I had to spend a lot of time optimizing the game. And I loved that challenge. For example, I had to find a way to draw blood into the ground texture, so it doesn't take extra memory and the game runs smooth.

Here are some screenshots:

Sadly, the game didn't get released by a publisher for some reason. Also, because we sold an exclusive license for this game, I can't publish it anywhere, but you can check out the trailer:

items.title: Monster Craft - A good idea is worth a lot
items.summary: So I was hanging out with my best friend and were brainstoring game…
items.content_html:
So I was hanging out with my best friend and were brainstoring game ideas. We weren't planning to develop one together - we just enjoyed discussing interesting game ideas.

That day we came up with the idea of MonsterCraft:

  • Take a basic combination logic: A+B=C and use it to craft units. Make the result logical: robot+robot = bigger robot, zombie+zombie = big zombie, robot+zombie = cyborg zombie!

I described the idea to the team I made Cortex Fortress with and we developed the game fairly quickly.

It was quite successful: we got a lot of good reviews and people started making walthroughs and letsplays of MonsterCraft on youtube. One of those videos got 7 million views:

Later we started to notice reskinned versions of our game on the web and android versions on Google Play Store:

We contacted Google to take those down. Eventually they did take down some of those, but new ones kept popping up and we gave up. I'd say proudly I accepted this as a sign of success and popularity.

If you want, you play MonsterCraft online on ArmorGames.

items.title: Cortex Fortress - Developing together
items.summary: After releasing my first game - BrainDef, I got my first fan!…
items.content_html:
After releasing my first game - BrainDef, I got my first fan!

It was not just an ordinary fan, it was a guy, experienced in making 2d and 3d art for games. He offered to join me and make another game for a 50\50 profits split when it goes live. I was so hyped back then! Later on he also invited his friend into our little team, who took care of SFX and music.

Those people helped me gain confidence and motivation to release my games faster and brought the quality level of my games way up.

You can watch this trailer:

Or play it here.

items.title: BrainDef - My first game
items.summary: Back in 2012, after reading a lot of success stories on flashgamedev.ru I…
items.content_html:
Back in 2012, after reading a lot of success stories on flashgamedev.ru I decided to try creating a game myself.

This was my first experience of programming. I used Adobe Flash (which uses ActionScript3 as a scripting language). I used this amazing tutorial to learn how to create a basic shooter game in Flash, and then just remixed it a little.

In this game you can find references to my favourite games of the time: Team Fortress 2, C&C, Wormix.

You can play BrainDef on Kongregate.

items.title: Animated banners - a first hobby job -
items.summary: On my first year of university I started earning some pocket money as a…
items.content_html:
On my first year of university I started earning some pocket money as a freelancer. It wasn't much, but it was fun. I always wanted to become an animator - and this job was basically about animating adverisement banners in Adobe Flash.

Here are some examples of those banners. For more you can look into my fl.ru profile.

 

The more I used Adobe Flash, the more creative I started getting. I found out that you can also do interactive stuff in flash, so I dived into simple scripting and created this: a plate-clock that shows real time, with a silly secret that you could find if you drag a knife or a fork with your mouse!

Here are some screenshots for those, who can't use flash in their browser:

  

This was an incredible experience and helped me learn basics of animation and scripting, which I later used to develop flash games.
